creator: dtrewren
title: Home made electric glass fusing kiln
materials_required: Altec PC 410 multi-program multi-step industrial temperature controller
Mild steel (for corner brackets, straight sections, and stop plate)
description: This project details the construction of a homemade electric glass fusing kiln from readily available or repurposed parts. The kiln is designed to reach and maintain a temperature of 800C for fusing glass, with a focus on even heating and controlled temperature changes to prevent thermal shock. The heating element is integrated into the lid for a better glass finish, and an industrial temperature controller is used for precise temperature management.
steps: Obtain or fabricate a robust enclosure, ideally an aluminium radio test enclosure, and ensure it is free from any lid.

Line the enclosure with ceramic fire blanket and then ceramic fire bricks using high-temperature adhesive for insulation. Cut bricks to a consistent depth, ensuring proper ventilation to avoid dust inhalation.
Construct a control box containing the Altec temperature controller, K-type thermocouple, and a 40A solid-state relay to regulate power to the heating element.
Fabricate the lid using ceramic fire bricks held together with mild steel corner brackets and straight sections. Secure these with self-threading cutting screws and attach a handle.
Select a heating element with sufficient power, aiming for around 2.5KW. An initial attempt with a resistive wire element proved unsatisfactory due to sagging and insufficient heat output.

Implement a final heating solution using eight 400W 240V bar style heating elements wired in parallel for a total of approximately 3.2KW. Use steel angle iron faced with copper strips as bus bars to efficiently conduct power to the elements.
Attach the lid to the enclosure with rear hinges and line the underside of the lid with additional ceramic fire blanket.
Use the temperature controller's automatic tuning mode to calibrate the kiln and optimize temperature control parameters.
Run the kiln at full power to record temperature data for analysis and optimization of glass firing sequences.

creator: dtrewren
title: Home made electric glass fusing kiln
materials_required: Altec PC 410 multi-program multi-step industrial temperature controller
description: This project details the construction of a homemade electric glass fusing kiln. The kiln is built from a repurposed aluminum radio test enclosure and uses ceramic insulation, a temperature controller, and heating elements to achieve the high temperatures necessary for glass fusing.
steps: Obtain a suitable enclosure, such as a large aluminum radio test enclosure.
Line the lower half of the enclosure with ceramic fire blanket and then ceramic fire brick, securing with high temperature adhesive. Cut bricks to size to maximize space.
Construct a control box containing the Altec temperature controller, K-type thermocouple, and 40A solid state relay to manage the heating element.
Build the enclosure lid using ceramic fire brick, mild steel corner brackets, and straight sections, securing with self-thread cutting screws. Add a handle.
Initially, a 2.5KW heating element was used, embedded in a channel in the lid. However, this was later replaced due to issues with sagging and insufficient power.

The final heating solution involved using eight 400W 240V bar style heating elements, supported by steel angle iron faced with copper bus bars. Connect the bus bars through the lid using copper wire and a ceramic connector block.
Attach the lid to the enclosure with rear hinges and line the underside with more ceramic fire blanket.
Use the Altec temperature controller's automatic tuning mode to calibrate the kiln and optimize temperature control.
Run the kiln at full power, recording temperature data to optimize the firing sequence programmed into the temperature controller.
Fuse glass and compare the results to items fused in a microwave kiln.
